title: datasciencelol
text:
Being a data scientist (to me) is having the ability to utilize statistics and algorithms to solve problems and create autonomous working systems. A data scientist should be an expert in theoretical computer science and programming ability to optimize systems in organizations.
Data scientists and statisticians both use statistics in their daily lives. I primarily believe the difference lies in some of the other tools that each use. Statisticians tend to use more mathematical and possibly econometric theory, whereas data scientists are primarily concerned with the computer science aspect of creating. I believe both have similar mindsets with day-to-day life, and each have desirable skillsets!
I love both of these areas to be frank. I think I prefer statistician work a bit more, but I love the automation and optimization part of data science. Ideally, I find a position in industry combining my favorite parts of both fields!

title: datasciencelol
text:
Second Code Section
Set variable y to be a list of Pedal Widths from the Iris dataset, then find the class, type, and structure of y.

y <- density(iris$Petal.Width)
class(y)

[1] "density"

typeof(y)

[1] "list"

structure(y)


Call:
    density.default(x = iris$Petal.Width)

Data: iris$Petal.Width (150 obs.);  Bandwidth 'bw' = 0.2518

       x                 y            
 Min.   :-0.6555   Min.   :0.0005272  
 1st Qu.: 0.3222   1st Qu.:0.0832811  
 Median : 1.3000   Median :0.2653324  
 Mean   : 1.3000   Mean   :0.2554014  
 3rd Qu.: 2.2778   3rd Qu.:0.4193541  
 Max.   : 3.2555   Max.   :0.4978541  


Now, use the plot function to create a density graph of Petal Width.
